tit.e: Nanbanboeki (a term concerning trade in old times in Japan)
Nanbanboeki (a term concerning trade in olden times in Japan)
tit.cmt: 以下説明が続くため、英語説明は削除しました。

sen.j: 南蛮貿易（なんばんぼうえき）とは、日本の商人とスペイン、ポルトガルの商人（南蛮人）との間で16世紀半ばから17世紀初期にかけて行われていた貿易である。
sen.e: Nanbanboeki indicates the trade that was carried on between merchants in Japan and those in Spain or Portugal in the era from around the middle of 16th century to the early 17th century.
Nanbanboeki indicates trade that was carried on between merchants in Japan and those in Spain or Portugal during the era from around the middle of sixteenth century to the early seventeenth century.

sen.j: 1543年に種子島にポルトガル船が到来した。
sen.e: A Portuguese ship arrived at Tanega-shima Island in 1543.
A Portuguese ship arrived at Tanega-shima Island in 1543.

sen.j: ポルトガル船はその前年すでに琉球に到着していた。
sen.e: Portuguese ships had already arrived at Ryukyu (present Okinawa) in the previous year.

sen.j: しかしながら、琉球人はポルトガル船がマラッカを攻撃して占拠したことを知っていて、交易を拒否した。
sen.e: However, having known that Portuguese ships attacked and occupied Malacca, people in Ryukyu refused trading with the Portuguese.

sen.e: However, having known that Portuguese ships attacked and occupied Malacca, people in Ryukyu refused to trade with the Portuguese.

sen.j: 一方、日本の商人はポルトガル商船との交易を歓迎した。
sen.e: However, merchants in Japan welcomed trade with Portuguese coming aboard their merchant ships.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: そのため、ポルトガル船はマラッカから日本に訪れるようになった。
sen.e: Therefore, Portuguese ships became to visit Japan from Malacca.

sen.j: 1557年にポルトガルがマカオの使用権を獲得すると、マカオを拠点として、日本・中国・ポルトガルの三国の商品が取引されるようになった。
sen.e: In 1557 when Portugal acquired the right of using Macao, goods in Japan, in China and in Portugal became to be traded with Macao as the trading center.
In 1557 when Portugal acquired the right of using Macao, goods in Japan, in China and in Portugal were traded with Macao as the trading center.

sen.j: 織田信長・豊臣秀吉は基本的に南蛮貿易を推奨した。
sen.e: Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI promoted nanbanboeki basically.

sen.j: スペインはポルトガルに遅れてアメリカ大陸を経由しての太平洋航路を開拓し、ルソン島のマニラを本拠として日本を訪れるようになった。
sen.e: With Spain having developed Pacific Ocean ship routes via the American continent, Spanish ships became to visit Japan following Portugal with their operation center placed at Manila in Luzon.
With Spain having developed Pacific Ocean shipping routes via the American continent, Spanish ships came to visit Japan following Portugal with their operation center located at Manila in Luzon.

sen.j: 徳川家康はスペインとの貿易に積極的姿勢を見せ、京都の商人田中勝介を当時スペイン領のヌエバ・エスパーニャ（メキシコ）に派遣した。
sen.e: Ieyasu TOKUGAWA adopted the posture of actively promoting trade with Spain, and sent Shosuke TANAKA, a merchant in Kyoto, to Nueva Espana (present Mexico) that was a territory of Spain at that time.

sen.j: また、ポルトガル商人に対しては生糸の独占的利益を得ていた為、これを削ぐことを目的として京都・堺・長崎の商人に糸割符仲間を結成させた。
sen.e: Against the Portuguese merchants who had exclusively gained profits from trade of raw silk, Ieyasu made merchants in Kyoto, in Sakai and in Nagasaki form itowappu nakama (the thread tally union) to diminish their profits.

sen.j: 家康の頃はキリスト教は禁止されてはいたものの貿易は推奨されていた。
sen.e: In Ieyasu's era, Christianity was banned but trade with Portugal and Spain were not prohibited.

sen.j: しかし、その後の江戸幕府は禁教政策に加え、西国大名が勢力を伸ばすことを警戒したので海外との貿易を制限するようになった。
sen.e: However, after that, the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), being afraid that daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) in western Japan would expand their power, imposed restrictions on foreign trade in addition to the ban of Christianity.

sen.j: 交易場所は平戸港と長崎港に限られるようになった。
sen.e: The sites where foreign trade could be carried on became restricted to the Hirado port and Nagasaki port.

sen.j: 1624年にスペイン船の来航が禁止され、1639年にポルトガル船の来航が禁止され、平戸での交易を禁止した。
sen.e: Then Spanish ships and Portuguese ships were prohibited from visiting Japan in 1624 and in 1938, respectively, prohibiting their trade at Hirado.

sen.j: このようにして鎖国体制が成立し、南蛮貿易は終了した。
sen.e: The national isolation policy was established in this way, consequently ending nanbanboeki.

sen.j: 火縄銃(種子島)はポルトガルの銃を模倣したものである。
sen.e: Matchlock guns (also called Tanega-shima Island) were imitations of Portuguese guns.

sen.j: 1543年、ポルトガル人Fernão Mendes Pintoが中国船で鹿児島県の種子島に漂着した。
sen.e: In 1543, Fernão Mendes Pinto, a Portuguese, drifted ashore Tanega-shima Island aboard a Chinese ship.

sen.e: Strictly speaking, from around 270 years before that, Japan imported gunpowder from China and primitive guns called teppo (literally, an iron barrel) existed in Japan.

sen.e: However, they were not made user-friendly to such an extent that they could not be used as a major weapon in fighting, being used only by farmers for expelling harmful animals.

sen.e: However, the matchlock guns brought to Japan at that time could be ignited easily, and allowed firing quickly at a speed incomparable with previous guns in Japan.

sen.j: 各地の大名は、伝来当初こそこの新兵器の実力を疑問視したが、合戦でその効果が証明されるとこぞって買い求め、自国での量産化に奔走した。
sen.e: At first, every daimyo doubted the real power of this new weapon, but as the effectiveness was confirmed through battles, they bought them and made every effort to mass-produce them in their respective territories.

sen.e: Use of matchlock guns spread at a high speed that was unusual compared even with world standards, and they became used throughout Japan in quite a short time, completely changing fighting styles in the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States).

sen.j: それまで船といえば船底が平たい和船と呼ばれる船しかなかった。
sen.e: Up to that time, all ships in Japan were so-called wasen (literally, Japanese ships) with a flat bottom.

sen.j: これでは海洋に出たときに波で船が揺れ遠洋航海は危険極まりないものであった。
sen.e: With these ships, it was quite dangerous to sail over oceans because they were swayed by waves on oceans.
With these ships, it was quite dangerous to sail over oceans because they were easily swayed by the waves.

sen.j: 南蛮貿易が始まるとヨーロッパからガレオン船と呼ばれる竜骨 (船)を使った現在我々が普通に見る船底が尖った波の揺れに強い船が入港されるようになった。
sen.e: When nanbanboeki started, ships with a keeled bottom, called galleon ships, which, with a now ordinary V-shaped bottom, were resistant to waves, became to enter ports in Japan.

sen.e: In the Genna and Kanei eras (1615 - 1644), the shuinsen that inherited features of wasen in addition to those of the junks and galleons, which had been used for sailing over oceans, became used mostly for shuinsen-using trade.
